questions.question: What is the name of the default Linux shell?

explanation.summary: The Korn shell (ksh) is an alternative Unix shell created by David Korn at Bell Labs, but it is not the default shell in most Linux distributions.
explanation.why: While the Korn shell is a powerful shell with strong scripting capabilities, Bash has become the standard default shell for Linux systems due to its wide adoption and feature set.

explanation.summary: There is no standard Linux shell called 'Bat.' This appears to be a distractor option. You may be thinking of 'cat' (a command) or 'batch' files, but neither is a shell.
explanation.why: 'Bat' is not a recognized Unix/Linux shell name. The main shells include Bash, Zsh, Fish, Korn, and C shell.

explanation.summary: Bash (Bourne Again SHell) is the default shell in most Linux distributions. Created in 1989 by Brian Fox for the GNU Project, Bash is a free software replacement for the Bourne shell (sh) and has become the standard command-line interface for Linux systems.
keyPoints: Default shell on most Linux distributions (Ubuntu, Debian, Fedora, CentOS, etc.)
Stands for 'Bourne Again SHell' - named after the original Bourne shell
Supports command-line editing and command history
Includes tab completion for commands and file names
Compatible with shell scripts written for the original Bourne shell
Provides advanced features like arrays, job control, and functions
features: Command history: Recall previously entered commands with arrow keys
Tab completion: Auto-complete commands, file names, and paths
Command-line editing: Navigate and edit commands with keyboard shortcuts
Shell scripting: Write automation scripts with loops, conditionals, and functions
Aliases and functions: Create shortcuts for frequently used commands
examples: When you open a terminal in Ubuntu, you're using Bash by default
Shell scripts starting with #!/bin/bash use Bash as the interpreter
The $ prompt typically indicates you're in a Bash shell

learnMore.title: All Things How - Default Shell in Linux

explanation.summary: The C shell (csh) and its successor tcsh are alternative Unix shells with syntax resembling the C programming language, but they are not the default shell in most Linux distributions.
explanation.why: C shell was popular in earlier Unix systems, particularly BSD Unix, but Bash became the standard for Linux due to better scripting capabilities and compatibility with the Bourne shell.

questions.question: Which keyboard key automatically completes commands in the default Linux shell?

explanation.summary: CTRL is a modifier key used in combination with other keys for various shortcuts, but it doesn't trigger tab completion by itself.
explanation.why: While CTRL is used in many Bash shortcuts (CTRL+C to cancel, CTRL+D to exit, CTRL+R for reverse search), tab completion specifically requires the TAB key.

explanation.summary: SHIFT is primarily used to type uppercase letters and access special characters on the keyboard, not for command completion.
explanation.why: SHIFT doesn't have a special function in Bash for auto-completion. Tab completion specifically uses the TAB key.

explanation.summary: ENTER executes the command you've typed, it doesn't auto-complete it.
explanation.why: Pressing ENTER submits your command to the shell for execution. For auto-completion, you need to press TAB before pressing ENTER.

explanation.summary: The TAB key triggers auto-completion in Bash, automatically completing commands, file names, directory paths, and variable names. This feature significantly improves efficiency by reducing typing and preventing typos.
keyPoints: Press TAB once to complete if there's only one match
Press TAB twice to show all possible completions if multiple matches exist
Works for commands, file names, directory paths, and variables
Case-sensitive completion
Can complete partial command names and paths
Saves time and prevents spelling errors
howItWorks: Type a few letters of a command or filename
If unique, Bash completes it automatically
If multiple matches, press TAB again to see options
Continue typing to narrow down, then press TAB again
examples: Type 'hos' and press TAB → completes to 'hostname'
Type 'cd /etc/net' and press TAB → completes to '/etc/network/'
Type 'ls Doc' and press TAB → completes to 'Documents/' if it exists
Type 'apt-' and press TAB twice → shows all apt- commands
Type 'echo $HO' and press TAB → completes to '$HOME'
explanation.additionalInfo: Tab completion is provided by the Readline library in Bash. You can press TAB multiple times if there are several matching options—Bash will cycle through possibilities or display a list of all matches.

questions.question: Which keyboard key retrieves the last command that you entered in the default Linux shell?

explanation.summary: INSERT is used to toggle between insert and overwrite modes when editing text, not for command history navigation.
explanation.why: The INSERT key doesn't interact with Bash command history. For navigating history, you need the arrow keys.

explanation.summary: BACKSPACE deletes the character to the left of the cursor when editing a command, but doesn't retrieve previous commands from history.
explanation.why: BACKSPACE is for editing the current command line, not for accessing command history. Use the UP arrow for history navigation.

explanation.summary: The UP arrow key navigates backward through your command history in Bash, retrieving previously entered commands. Each press of the UP arrow moves one command further back in history, starting with the most recently executed command.
keyPoints: Press UP arrow to recall the previous command
Press UP arrow repeatedly to go further back in history
Press DOWN arrow to move forward through history
Retrieved commands can be edited before re-executing
Command history is saved across sessions
Default history size is typically 500-1000 commands
historyNavigation: UP arrow: Move backward through history (older commands)
DOWN arrow: Move forward through history (newer commands)
CTRL+R: Reverse search through history (type to search)
history command: Display entire command history
examples: Press UP arrow once to see your last command
Press UP arrow multiple times to find a command you ran earlier
Retrieve a command, edit it, and press ENTER to run the modified version
Use CTRL+R and type 'ssh' to search for the last SSH command you used
explanation.additionalInfo: Bash stores command history in the ~/.bash_history file. You can view your entire history with the 'history' command, and you can search through it using CTRL+R for reverse incremental search.

explanation.summary: ESC is used in vi mode for Bash to switch between insert and command modes, but it's not the standard way to retrieve command history.
explanation.why: In default emacs mode (standard Bash), ESC doesn't navigate history. The UP arrow is the standard key for accessing previous commands.

questions.question: Which command displays the name of the account that you are logged in as in the default Linux shell?

explanation.summary: The whoami command prints the username of the current effective user. It's a simple, quick way to verify which account you're logged in as, especially useful in multi-user systems or when switching between users with su or sudo.
keyPoints: Displays the current logged-in username
Shows the effective user ID (what the system sees you as)
Useful when you've used su or sudo and need to confirm your identity
No arguments needed - just type 'whoami'
Returns only the username, nothing else
Works on all Unix-like systems
useCases: Verifying your identity after switching users with su
Confirming you're not accidentally running commands as root
In scripts to check which user is running the script
Troubleshooting permission issues by confirming current user
Learning purposes to understand Linux user concepts
examples: In a script: if [ $(whoami) != 'root' ]; then echo 'Run as root'; fi
explanation.additionalInfo: whoami is equivalent to running 'id -un' (display user name from user ID). It's part of the GNU coreutils package and has been a standard Unix command since the early days of Unix.

explanation.summary: The wc (word count) command is used to count lines, words, and characters in files, not to display the current username.
explanation.why: wc is a text processing tool. For example, 'wc file.txt' would show line count, word count, and byte count of file.txt. It has nothing to do with user accounts.

explanation.summary: The login command is used to log in to the system as a different user, not to display the current username.
explanation.why: 'login' initiates a new login session and prompts for username and password. It doesn't display your current account information—it changes your account.

explanation.summary: The history command displays a list of previously executed commands with line numbers, not the current username.
explanation.why: 'history' shows your command history—a numbered list of commands you've run in the shell. It doesn't provide user account information.

questions.question: Which command displays the name of the computer that you are logged in to in the default Linux shell?

explanation.summary: The cal command displays a calendar, not the computer's hostname.
explanation.why: 'cal' shows a formatted calendar for the current month or specified month/year. It has nothing to do with system identification.

explanation.summary: The id command displays user identity information (UID, GID, and group memberships), not the hostname.
explanation.why: 'id' shows user ID, group ID, and group memberships for the current user or specified user. While useful for user information, it doesn't display the computer's name.

explanation.summary: The host command is a DNS lookup tool used to query DNS servers and resolve domain names to IP addresses, not to display the local hostname.
explanation.why: 'host' performs DNS lookups. For example, 'host google.com' returns IP addresses for google.com. To get your computer's name, use 'hostname'.

explanation.summary: The hostname command displays or sets the system's network name (hostname). This is the name that identifies your computer on a network and appears in your command prompt. It helps you confirm which machine you're working on, especially when managing multiple systems.
keyPoints: Displays the computer's network name
Shows the name that identifies your system on a network
Useful for confirming which machine you're logged into
Can also be used to set the hostname (with root privileges)
Different options show different name formats (short name, FQDN, etc.)
The hostname appears in your shell prompt by default
commonOptions: hostname -f: Display the FQDN (Fully Qualified Domain Name)
hostname -i: Display the IP address(es) of the host
hostname -I: Display all IP addresses of the host
hostname -s: Display the short hostname (before first dot)
useCases: Verifying which server you're connected to via SSH
Confirming you're on the correct system before running critical commands
Including the hostname in scripts or logs for identification
Documenting which system a backup or configuration came from
examples: When logged into server 'db-prod-01': $ hostname → Returns: db-prod-01
explanation.additionalInfo: The hostname is stored in /etc/hostname and is set during system boot. You'll also see it in your shell prompt (user@hostname:~$). When connecting to remote servers via SSH, knowing the hostname confirms you're on the right machine before making changes.
